intro: Trachyspermum involucratum, commonly known as Indian cumin or wild cumin, is an annual herb native to regions of southern and eastern Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbellate flowers. The plant produces small, spherical fruits that are rich in essential oils, contributing to its aromatic properties. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry, open habitats. Trachyspermum involucratum is valued for its use in traditional medicine and as a spice in various cuisines.
